stream_context.summary: Kaze finishes major Overworld scripting work around the “Old Man Yoshi” (hint system + dialogue/pop-up pipeline) and starts designing the next big Overworld feature (Athlete Yoshi), pivoting it from a Rainbow Ride-style idea into short stadium races that award multiple stars. He also does a real-N64 performance/profiling check showing the Overworld area can effectively hit ~60fps without anti-aliasing, then measures the AA cost and sets the next optimization target.
stream_context.significance_reason: He closes out a substantial Overworld NPC/hint system (plus completes two stars) and demonstrates near-60fps performance on real N64 hardware with profiling, establishing a concrete optimization milestone and the next performance target (60fps with AA).

findings.summary: Course 12 was reworked to make the critical “Dairy Bar” easier to find; Kaze replaces a foggy outskirts transition with a minecart ride and shrinks the outskirts to reduce aimless wandering.
Kaze notes Course 12 still needs NPC text for a character that hints at a nearby secret door, emphasizing his approach of using dialogue to guide secrets rather than pure obscurity.

Overworld progress update: parts 1–4 are finished; part 5 (the main village where the Yoshis live) is the biggest section and nearly done; many remaining parts are already modeled and mostly awaiting programming, making Kaze feel the project is “more than halfway done” in practice.

Kaze argues ROMhacking/derivative works are a core reason Mario 64 remains culturally relevant today, framing modding as a way for a classic to “flourish and grow” beyond being treated as a static brand product.

Kaze estimates RTYI’s 60fps mode substantially reduces input latency versus vanilla Mario 64: he cites ~105–110ms in original, and roughly ~51ms at 60fps due to higher-frequency buffering/present cadence (even if other parts only improve a few ms).

Camera design philosophy: Kaze dislikes “parallel camera” (axis-aligned camera) because it feels “too gamey” and world-axis dependent; he prefers a camera that rotates the minimum necessary to keep Mario centered and can temporarily disable auto-rotation via C-buttons until camera/movement realign.
findings.quote: I think a camera should be agnostic to the world axis.

findings.summary: Old Man Yoshi NPC implementation: Kaze uses a simple pop-up dialogue system (set desired pop-up ID, then reset to 0) and begins building a new data structure mapping text IDs to star completion states so the NPC can provide hints in a specific order and stop once all hints are exhausted.

A major bug remains: the overworld star collection text/cutscene sometimes fails to end properly even after initial fixes, indicating a systemic issue in the Overworld star cutscene flow that needs dedicated debugging.

Rendering-layer issue spotted: smoke/particle effects appear in the wrong order relative to shadows/decals; Kaze suspects legacy particle behavior from an older codepath (“MRO-64 particle”) and discusses intended render layers (particles vs shadows/transparent decals).

Athlete Yoshi design pivots: instead of launching the player to a Rainbow Ride-style slide, Kaze proposes making Athlete Yoshi rideable and initiating short stadium races (30–45s) against ~7 Yoshis with cheering spectators (potentially 2D billboards). The same NPC interaction would award three different stars across three escalating races, also helping “inflate” the star count (Kaze cites ~192 stars at this point).

Race economy/structure idea: Kaze considers an entry fee so “money needs to do something,” but notes they never made a new coin icon; he also wants races to differ enough to avoid three near-identical laps (difficulty escalation, obstacles/time-trial variants discussed).

Performance milestone on real N64: using an in-game profiler with 800-frame averaging, Kaze sees ~59–60fps in a consistent Overworld test spot without anti-aliasing. RDP timing suggests ~57.7fps by calculation, implying profiling/pipeline measurement nuances. Enabling anti-aliasing drops performance to ~52fps (~12% frame-time increase), defining the next optimization goal: hit 60fps with AA.
Biobak joins in chat during the Athlete Yoshi brainstorming and later reacts to implementation details (including suggesting changes and discussing visibility/view-maximization decisions).
Kaze publicly posts the project progress tracker link in his second-channel description during stream to make progress visible to viewers.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides real-time feedback during the Athlete Yoshi redesign discussion, validating the stadium-race approach as stronger than the earlier Rainbow Ride concept and contributing suggestions around race variety/difficulty.

Biobak asks Kaze to change where the progress tracker is placed (Kaze declines, preferring maximum views), illustrating small but practical push-pull between documentation/community UX and channel strategy.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think a camera should be agnostic to the world axis.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why he avoids the popular axis-aligned “parallel camera” used by many Mario 64 modders, tying camera behavior to immersion and world believability.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I wouldn't want to put out a game that I myself would refuse to play.
memorable_quotes.context: Motivating why he keeps reworking engine feel/performance (and why vanilla Mario 64 no longer meets his own standards).

key_stories.title: Course 12 navigation redesign to surface the Dairy Bar
key_stories.summary: Kaze revisits Course 12 after an initial version he calls poor, focusing on improving player readability and ensuring a key location (the Dairy Bar) is discovered naturally. He replaces a fog-heavy outskirts transition with a minecart transport sequence and reduces the outskirts size, keeping the level’s strongest setpiece while minimizing confusion.
key_stories.challenge: Players might miss the Dairy Bar, but the bar is important to the course’s flow and content; the earlier layout made the approach unclear and meandering.
key_stories.process: Identify the navigation failure, then redesign the traversal: shrink the outskirts and create a more explicit minecart route into the important hub, plus plan NPC dialogue to hint secrets (e.g., secret door).
key_stories.outcome: A clearer, more directed Course 12 structure is in place, with remaining work mainly in hint text and cleanup (plus unrelated Fast64 visibility bugs).
key_stories.key_quote: It's very important that the player finds the Dairy Bar.

key_stories.title: Old Man Yoshi hint system and persistent star-cutscene bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements and validates the Overworld’s “Old Man Yoshi” as a guided hint dispenser, using a lightweight pop-up dialogue mechanism and starting a structured mapping from text IDs to star progress. While the hint content and ordering are nearing completion, a serious issue remains: the overworld star text/cutscene sometimes does not terminate correctly.
key_stories.challenge: Build a robust hint NPC that responds to player progress, while also avoiding UI glitches (mis-centered text) and cutscene state bugs that can soft-lock pacing.
key_stories.process: Use the pop-up dialogue system (set ID then reset), add a star-to-hint mapping structure for ordered hints, test in-game, then instrument/debug the cutscene-ending logic when it fails.
key_stories.outcome: The hint NPC is close to “finished,” but the cutscene-end bug is explicitly logged for future debugging and is still blocking full confidence in the overworld star-collection flow.
key_stories.key_quote: The cutscene not ending is not awesome, though. That's a problem.

key_stories.title: Athlete Yoshi pivots from Rainbow Ride concept to stadium racing stars
key_stories.summary: Kaze reassesses an earlier plan where Athlete Yoshi would launch the player skyward toward a Rainbow Ride-like slide. He decides this is less compelling than making Athlete Yoshi rideable and turning the interaction into a series of short, escalating stadium races that each award a star, with crowds and spectacle emphasizing Yoshi culture in the village.
key_stories.challenge: Make Athlete Yoshi content feel worthy of a major overworld character, avoid a one-off gimmick, and prevent repetitive objectives while also supporting the project’s large star count goals.
key_stories.process: Brainstorm race length and structure (30–45 seconds), crowd presentation (billboard spectators), and progression (three different stars, rising difficulty, obstacles/time-trial variants). Consider an entry fee to give currency purpose.
key_stories.outcome: A new feature direction is chosen that better fits the “ride Yoshi” fantasy and can scale into multiple stars; implementation sequencing (build stadium first vs later) remains to be decided.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like if we have an Athlete Yoshi, then he should also be rideable.

key_stories.title: Real N64 profiling confirms near-60fps and sets AA target
key_stories.summary: Kaze runs an N64 test using an 800-frame averaging profiler to measure stable performance in a consistent Overworld spot. The scene effectively reaches 60fps without anti-aliasing, while RDP timing math suggests ~57.7fps, revealing measurement/pipeline nuance; enabling anti-aliasing drops to ~52fps, defining the next engine optimization goal.
key_stories.challenge: Prove the decomp-based RTYI engine can sustain a modern-feeling frame rate on original hardware, then quantify the real cost of visual features like anti-aliasing.
key_stories.process: Use built-in CPU/FPS averaging and an RDP profiler to collect frame-time data; compare displayed FPS to RDP-derived FPS; toggle AA and measure delta.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete milestone is achieved (near-60fps baseline), and the next performance milestone is clearly identified (60fps with AA).
key_stories.key_quote: I think we can say that we have managed to hit 60 fps here.

open_questions.context: Even after changes, Kaze observes the overworld star text/cutscene still failing to terminate properly, implying a broader state/flag issue in the overworld star-collection flow.
questions: What exact conditions reproduce the non-ending cutscene (specific stars, specific areas, first-time vs repeat)?
Is the bug tied to a missing dialogue response/text ID path, course number handling, or a custom overworld-star script diverging from vanilla SM64?
How does Kaze want overworld star collection to differ from course star collection (UI, control lockout, camera, text)?

open_questions.context: Kaze calculates ~57.7fps from RDP time (~17.34ms), yet the averaged FPS display shows ~59–60, suggesting pipelining/measurement differences.
questions: Which metric does Kaze consider authoritative for ‘real’ framerate in RTYI: CPU frame start/end, VI rate, or RDP completion time?
What pipeline behavior (triple buffering, VI scheduling, RDP/CPU overlap) explains the mismatch, and how should it be communicated in the documentary without oversimplifying?
Did this discrepancy appear in other scenes or only the chosen test spot?

open_questions.context: AA drops the tested area from near-60 to ~52fps (~12% frame-time increase). Kaze frames the next step as achieving 60fps with AA enabled.
questions: What specific optimizations are on the table to ‘buy back’ the AA cost (geometry reduction, display-list changes, RDP state changes, texture format changes, culling)?
Is AA intended as a default setting for final release, or a toggle depending on hardware/emulator?
Will the project support multiple render paths (AA/no-AA) and how will that affect QA/testing?

open_questions.context: Kaze proposes rideable Athlete Yoshi stadium races with 3 stars, entry fee, spectators, and escalating difficulty, but details are undecided.
questions: How will Kaze implement competing Yoshis (AI/pathing/rubber-banding), and what existing code (e.g., Yoshi Garden behavior) will be reused?
What prevents the three races from feeling like the same lap repeated—obstacles, route changes, hazards, time trials, crowd/arena evolution?
How will the entry fee/currency loop work without a new coin icon, and what does money meaningfully unlock elsewhere in the overworld?

open_questions.context: Kaze stresses the player must find the Dairy Bar and restructures the level around that, implying it’s a key hub or gating point.
questions: What role does the Dairy Bar play mechanically (quests, stars, upgrades, story beats), and why is it critical to discovery order?
How does the minecart transition support the mood/theme of Course 12 compared to the earlier foggy outskirts concept?
What player-testing feedback or internal playtest observations led to calling the first build ‘ass’?
